captions.text: Hello and welcome to world news today.
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: If you want a new adventure and have a lot of money you could soon book a trip to the International Space Station.
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: On Friday, NASA announced it will open the International Space Station for tourism and business.
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: There will be up to two private missions per year.
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: We are allowing private astronaut missions to the International Space Station.
captions.speaker: speaker

captions.text: NASA will support up to two private missions per year starting as early as 2020.
captions.speaker: speaker

captions.text: These private missions will allow approved commercial activities on the station.
captions.speaker: speaker

captions.text: Keith Cowing is an astrobiologist and former NASA employee who edits the online blog NASA Watch.
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: Keith, what do you make of this?
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: It's not surprising. The space station has had commercial visitors before by the Russians, but it was improvised.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: Now NASA has clarified the process for doing commercial activities in the space station.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: It's clear now, like an advert for a resort where you can choose activities and then pay.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: What's the incentive? Bringing more private money into space research?
captions.speaker: presenter

captions.text: There has been interest in commercializing the space station for many years.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: With NASA's plans to return to the moon, they are looking to offset some costs.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: But President Trump tweeted that NASA should not talk about going back to the moon, so things might change.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: The idea is to move routine activities closer to Earth, save money, and fund NASA's exploration of new frontiers.
captions.speaker: interviewee

captions.text: It's about re-balancing payments for a bigger plan of exploration.
captions.speaker: interviewee
